Comments_List: it was good to practice presenting about my work
This course was mainly about figuring out which direction we'll want to take for our senior projects. It was helpful to speak with students from different concentrations.
I got feedback on the senior project.

An ability to describe my artist practice. 
Developing inquiries that are relevant to my practice.
Giving feedback to fellow art majors, especially those whose work and interests greatly differ from mine.
the work you put in to your senior thesis is on you -- you'll get out of it what you put into it
I had the (very cool) opportunity to be inspired by my peers' work and learn about their past, current, and future work.

This course is the senior thesis class for the fall semester, and was comprised mostly of student presentations. This course mainly functions as a way for students to communicate about their ideas and progress.
Sessions feel very long and not always productive.
it is pretty fun seeing what other people are working on

Course was presentation based; each student had to give 2 presentations on past/ongoing work over course of term. Would have been helpful to have some individualized direction earlier in the termwe did not get advisor assignments until very late.
We should probably break up into smaller sections or something....
The class has too many people enrolled in it to promote active discussions. I would suggest that when there are too many art majors, the class be divided into two sections.
not particularly helpful for critique; nice to see what your peers are working on

Strength: I loved hearing people talk about their work. It's weird that, before senior year, we don't have more spaces for us to hear about the work of other Art majors.

Weakness: I wish the class was more than just student presentations. This made the class very low-stress, which was nice, but it also made the class a bit less engaging than it otherwise might be. I wish we were learning skills that were applicable in some way. Maybe some kind of student-led workshop would be nice, to emphasize the importance of interdisciplinary learning across the arts? (i.e. Computing and the Arts students could lead a class on coding-based graphics, Graphic Design students could lead a class on the history of typography, Painting students could lead a class on color theory, etc.) Learning how to talk about your work is important, but we only presented twice (15 minutes each) for the whole semester, so the amount of learning was a bit limited.

I did not think this course was very engaging. The presentations were required to include certain information (such as inspiration and related literature) which could be important to some projects, but may not be as applicable for others. It think it would be better if students were given guidelines for the presentations, but were not required to talk about all of the topics.
well you gotta take it but that's ok
Yes; it's great to engage with your peers directly in a setting like this.
You have no choice.
If you are an art major.
It is a mandatory course for art majors.
It's required! I didn't come into the class feeling very excited, but I was pleasantly surprised by how engaged/inspired I was with the work of my peers.
This class is only open to Art and Computing and the Arts majors.
